private_information: I hold the following disks on my peg from top to bottom: A, B, C, D, E, F
Disk A is the smallest and disk F is the largest
left_peg.goal: Move all disks to the right peg preserving the order from smallest on top to largest on bottom.

middle_peg.goal: Move all disks to the right peg preserving the order from smallest on top to largest on bottom.

right_peg.goal: Move all disks to the right peg preserving the order from smallest on top to largest on bottom.

orchestrator.goal: Move all disks to the right peg preserving the order from smallest on top to largest on bottom.

public_information: This is a Tower of Hanoi instance with three pegs named left, middle, and right.
There are 6 disks labeled A, B, C, D, E, F from smallest to largest where A is the smallest and F is the largest.
Only one disk may be moved at a time.
You may never place a larger disk on top of a smaller disk.
Initially the left peg holds disks top to bottom A, B, C, D, E, F and the other pegs are empty.
The goal is to have the right peg hold disks top to bottom A, B, C, D, E, F while left and middle pegs are empty.

describe.system_prompt: You are the left peg agent. Provide a concise and precise description of the current stack of disks on your peg in top to bottom order and identify which disk is at the top and therefore movable. Do not produce PDDL. Do not make assumptions about other pegs beyond the public information.
describe.prompt: Your name is left_peg. Use the public information about the environment and your private information to describe your peg state. State which disk is on top and list the stack top to bottom. Output a clear machine readable description suitable for an orchestrator to construct a planning problem.

describe.system_prompt: You are the middle peg agent. Provide a concise and precise description of the current stack of disks on your peg in top to bottom order and identify which disk is at the top and therefore movable. Do not produce PDDL. Do not make assumptions about other pegs beyond the public information.
describe.prompt: Your name is middle_peg. Use the public information about the environment and your private information to describe your peg state. State which disk is on top and list the stack top to bottom. Output a clear machine readable description suitable for an orchestrator to construct a planning problem.

describe.system_prompt: You are the right peg agent. Provide a concise and precise description of the current stack of disks on your peg in top to bottom order and identify which disk is at the top and therefore movable. Do not produce PDDL. Do not make assumptions about other pegs beyond the public information.
describe.prompt: Your name is right_peg. Use the public information about the environment and your private information to describe your peg state. State which disk is on top and list the stack top to bottom. Output a clear machine readable description suitable for an orchestrator to construct a planning problem.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in PDDL and you will produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem suitable for the FastDownwards planner. Integrate the peg state descriptions provided by the peg agents and the public information to generate a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem encoding the Tower of Hanoi instance. The domain must model pegs, disks, disk sizes, and allowed move actions with preconditions and effects that enforce that only the top disk from a peg may be moved and that a larger disk cannot be placed on a smaller disk. The problem must list all disks and pegs, set the initial configuration according to the provided states, and set the goal configuration where the right peg holds disks top to bottom A, B, C, D, E, F and the other pegs are empty. Target the FastDownwards solver and produce files that are syntactically correct PDDL. Enclose the domain between <domain> and </domain> tags and the problem between <problem> and </problem> tags.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. Use the public environment information and the peg state descriptions received from the agents to build a full PDDL domain and problem for FastDownwards. Here is the public information: This is a Tower of Hanoi instance with three pegs named left, middle, and right. There are 6 disks labeled A, B, C, D, E, F from smallest to largest. Only one disk may be moved at a time. You may never place a larger disk on top of a smaller disk. Initially the left peg holds disks top to bottom A, B, C, D, E, F and the other pegs are empty. The goal is to have the right peg hold disks top to bottom A, B, C, D, E, F while left and middle pegs are empty. Here are the states reported by agents: state_left: {state_left} state_middle: {state_middle} state_right: {state_right} Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem encoding the instance and suitable for FastDownwards. Enclose the domain between <domain> and </domain> and the problem between <problem> and </problem>.
